trial_identification.studytitle: Proof of principle study of transabdominal gastrointestinal stimulation (TAGS) for adult constipation.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Proof of principle study of the efficacy of transabdominal gastrointestinal stimulation (TAGS) for the treatment of adult constipation.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: A four month treatment period whereby the patient applies non invasive transabdominal gastrointestinal stimulation (TAGS) for one hour per day using a convenient garment that houses the electrodes. TAGS delivers a safe electrical stimulation to the abdomen. The stimulation parameters used are in common use by physiotherapists for treating pain (4,000hz carrier with a sweep frequency between 80 -160Hz) at a current level that is comfortable for each patient.
interventions.comparator: This is an proof of principle uncontrolled study

secondaryOutcome.outcome: * Defaecation frequency, volume, consistency recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Frequency of straining during defecation, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Feeling of incomplete evacuation, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Abdominal pain, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Bloating, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Effect on daily activities, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Need for manual assistance to evacuate, recorded by the patient in the study diary
* Laxative use, recorded by the patient in the study diary
Quality of life (QOL) - (PAC-QOL) recorded by the patient in the PAC QOL questionnaire form

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: * Patients aged between 18 and 75 with chronic functional idiopathic constipation as defined by a > 6 month history of: a) Less than or equal to two spontaneous complete bowel movement (SCBM)/week for at least 6 months prior to recruitment b) At least 25% of the time suffer from at least one symptoms of: lumpy/hard stools, sensation of incomplete evacuation, need to strain during defaecation
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: * Constipation secondary to endocrine causes, metabolic causes or neurological conditions * Known or suspected organic disorders of the large bowel * Serious chronic medical condition * Surgical procedure on the large bowel or rectum * Pregnancy or planning to become pregnant * Insufficient comprehension of English requiring a translator * Implanted cardiac defibrillator or pacemaker

trial_design.concealment: All patients that meet the inclusion criteria included. No randomisation
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Qualitative assessment. No sample size calculation was performed.

recruitment.hospital: John Hunter Hospital Royal Newcastle Centre - New Lambton

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A pilot study to assess the effectiveness of a medical device to treat chronic constipation in adults
